articles.title: At the heart of change: Spotlight Initiative highlights breakthroughs in tackling gender-based violence
articles.summary: When it comes to protecting women and girls from gender-based violence, change happens when they are “at the heart of every decision,” according to Erin Kenny, Global Coordinator of the Spotlight Initiative a United Nations–European Union partnership aimed at tackling all forms of abuse against women and girls.
articles.content:
At the heart of change: Spotlight Initiative highlights breakthroughs in tackling gender-based violence

When it comes to protecting women and girls from gender-based violence, change happens when they are “at the heart of every decision,”according to Erin Kenny, Global Coordinator of the Spotlight Initiative a United Nations–European Union partnership aimed at tackling all forms of abuse against women and girls.

Since 2017, Spotlight, has been working to prevent violence, sexual and gender-based violence (GBV), as well as femicide, human trafficking, and labour exploitation.

Worldwide, one in three women has experienced physical or sexual violence, and in many places, this number is even higher.

Here are some of the initiative’s major breakthroughs highlighted in a report focusing on its innovative approaches, and its sustained achievements over the past seven years.

Finding empowerment in Zimbabwe

© UNESCO In Zimbabwe, rural women with disabilities meet to advocate for their rights.

In Zvimba, Ndakaitei Matare, a mother of one and chair of a disability support group, knows firsthand the challenges of living with a disability having faced, since an early age, barriers to education, assistive devices, and economic opportunities.

Through a partnership between Spotlight and the government, Ndakaitei and other women with disabilities have found empowerment, raising awareness through disability support groups about GBV, rights and inclusion.

“We are capable of doing a lot if we unite and work together,” she said, a testament to how knowledge and community can transform lives.

Access to justice for women

Since, access to justice for survivors of sexual violence has significantly improved. Victim-Friendly Courts now offer safe spaces for women and children, and the Judicial Services Commission continues to support survivors with transport and food allowances and has expanded three more courts with separation rooms.

Supporting child survivors in Haiti

© UNICEF/Herold Joseph A teenage survivor of gender-based violence is recovering in Haiti.

In summer 2023, Taina* was kidnapped and held captive for a week by a Haitian gang.

She recalled being held in a residence where two men raped her one after the other, describing it as a ‘nightmare week’.

While others were also held captive, she was the only minor.

Thanks to Spotlight, Taina received medical, psychological, and social support, housing, microfinance and income-generation training, school fee assistance, and emergency relocation.

"In this environment, I could finally breathe," said Taina.

She now looks to the future with determination, dreaming of becoming a police officer and planning to resume her studies while pursuing courses in beauty treatment and cooking.

Tackling sexual violence

More than one in three Haitian women has experienced violence from a partner or husband. Nearly 30 per cent of women of childbearing age have suffered physical violence — almost half from an intimate partner. Twelve per cent have experienced sexual violence, including many girls aged 15 to 17.

Supporting women migrant workers' rights in Thailand

© ILO/Chalalai Taesilapasathit Migrant workers like Namwaan* need support to ensure safe and decent jobs.

Namwaan* left Myanmar in 2003 to pursue a better life in Thailand.

The first job she found was in a textile factory. She recalled working long hours for little income. “I had to work 12-16 hours per day for only 70 baht ($3).”

Invisible, exploited, abused, silenced. These are just some of the words used by women migrant workers to describe their working conditions.

As Namwaan didn’t read or speak Thai, she was not able to negotiate her working conditions and she feared she’d be punished by her employer if she tried to speak up.

“Some of my colleagues were harassed, locked up, or faced physical abuse when they spoke up about their working conditions,” she said.

Recovering from abuse

Through awareness campaigns, support desks located at airports, and service provider training, the Spotlight Initiative has explained therisks faced by women migrant workers.

For Namwann, the training offered a space to connect with others who had faced similar abuse.

"I felt completely connected to their stories," she said. "This programme gives millions of women hope for decent work free from violence."

Banning corporal punishment in Tajikistan

In 2023, Tajikistan became the 66th country in the world to ban corporal punishment, a transformative policy shift which was made possible through the Spotlight Initiative.

© UNICEF/M. Ruziev A mother and her three children stand outside their home in Tajikistan.

Partnering with the Ministry of Health, the initiative established 15 victim support rooms — offering integrated medical, psychological, and referral services, including short-term shelter.

More notably, transformation extended into communities — strengthening the role of religious leaders as advocates for gender equality and key actors in violence prevention efforts.

In more than 300 schools, Spotlight supported the creation of a national incident reporting mechanism which the government took full ownership of and publicly committed to expanding nationwide by 2030.

articles.reasoning: The article reports on the Spotlight Initiative, a significant UN-EU partnership that has made meaningful progress in combating gender-based violence globally. It highlights concrete improvements such as empowerment of women with disabilities in Zimbabwe, improved justice access for survivors, support for child survivors in Haiti, protection for migrant women workers in Thailand, and policy change banning corporal punishment in Tajikistan. These achievements have broad societal impact, focus on a single important topic, and provide detailed examples of positive change.
articles.personality_title: Spotlight Initiative drives progress against violence targeting women and girls
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Gender-based violence affects millions of women and girls worldwide, with one in three experiencing physical or sexual abuse. The Spotlight Initiative is a partnership between the United Nations and the European Union that began in 2017 to fight all forms of violence against women and girls.

**What happened** – Over the past seven years, the Spotlight Initiative has helped many survivors and pushed for changes in laws and communities. In Zimbabwe, women with disabilities formed support groups to raise awareness about their rights. Courts have become safer for survivors, providing special rooms and assistance. In Haiti, a teenage girl who survived gang violence received medical and psychological help, education support, and training. In Thailand, migrant women workers gained protection through awareness campaigns and training. Tajikistan banned corporal punishment and set up victim support rooms with the initiative’s help.

**Impact** – These efforts show real progress by focusing on survivors’ needs and involving communities. For example, the support for disabled women in Zimbabwe helps them speak out and unite. Safe courtrooms mean survivors can seek justice more easily. Helping a young survivor in Haiti shows how support can change a life. Protecting migrant workers in Thailand addresses hidden abuse in workplaces. The ban on corporal punishment in Tajikistan marks an important legal step to protect children and reduce violence.

**What's next step** – Countries involved plan to keep expanding these programs. Tajikistan aims to grow its school reporting system nationwide by 2030. Other places will continue offering training, support services, and legal reforms to help more survivors and prevent violence.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Spotlight Initiative’s work over seven years has made lasting changes that help women and girls worldwide find safety, justice, and new opportunities.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’initiative Spotlight fait avancer la lutte contre la violence envers les femmes et les filles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La violence basée sur le genre touche des millions de femmes et de filles dans le monde, une sur trois ayant subi des violences physiques ou sexuelles. L’initiative Spotlight est un partenariat entre les Nations Unies et l’Union européenne lancé en 2017 pour combattre toutes les formes de violence contre les femmes et les filles.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Depuis sept ans, l’initiative Spotlight aide les survivantes et pousse à des changements légaux et communautaires. Au Zimbabwe, des femmes handicapées ont créé des groupes de soutien pour défendre leurs droits. Des tribunaux ont été adaptés pour offrir un espace sûr aux victimes. En Haïti, une adolescente survivante d’une violence de gang a reçu un soutien médical, psychologique, scolaire et une formation. En Thaïlande, les femmes migrantes ont bénéficié de campagnes de sensibilisation et de formations. Le Tadjikistan a interdit les châtiments corporels et mis en place des espaces d’aide pour les victimes grâce à cette initiative.

**Impact** – Ces actions montrent un vrai progrès en centrant les efforts sur les besoins des survivantes et en impliquant les communautés. Par exemple, le soutien aux femmes handicapées au Zimbabwe leur permet de s’exprimer et de s’unir. Des tribunaux sécurisés facilitent la justice. L’aide apportée à la jeune Haïtienne change une vie. La protection des travailleuses migrantes en Thaïlande lutte contre des abus cachés. L’interdiction des châtiments corporels au Tadjikistan est une avancée légale majeure pour protéger les enfants.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays concernés comptent étendre ces programmes. Le Tadjikistan prévoit de généraliser son système de signalement dans les écoles d’ici 2030. D’autres régions continueront à offrir formations, soutiens et réformes pour aider plus de survivantes et prévenir la violence.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En sept ans, l’initiative Spotlight a permis des changements durables pour aider les femmes et les filles dans le monde à trouver sécurité, justice et nouvelles opportunités.
articles.personality_title_es: La iniciativa Spotlight impulsa avances contra la violencia hacia mujeres y niñas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La violencia de género afecta a millones de mujeres y niñas en todo el mundo, una de cada tres ha sufrido violencia física o sexual. La iniciativa Spotlight es una asociación entre las Naciones Unidas y la Unión Europea que comenzó en 2017 para combatir todas las formas de violencia contra mujeres y niñas.

**Qué pasó** – En siete años, la iniciativa Spotlight ha ayudado a sobrevivientes y promovido cambios legales y comunitarios. En Zimbabue, mujeres con discapacidad crearon grupos de apoyo para defender sus derechos. Los tribunales se volvieron más seguros para las víctimas, con espacios especiales y ayuda. En Haití, una adolescente sobreviviente de violencia de pandillas recibió apoyo médico, psicológico, educativo y capacitación. En Tailandia, trabajadoras migrantes obtuvieron protección mediante campañas y capacitaciones. Tayikistán prohibió el castigo corporal y estableció espacios de apoyo a víctimas con ayuda de la iniciativa.

**Impacto** – Estos esfuerzos muestran avances reales al enfocarse en las necesidades de las sobrevivientes e involucrar a las comunidades. Por ejemplo, el apoyo a mujeres discapacitadas en Zimbabue les permite unirse y expresarse. Los tribunales seguros facilitan el acceso a la justicia. Ayudar a la joven en Haití cambió su vida. Proteger a las trabajadoras migrantes en Tailandia combate abusos ocultos. La prohibición del castigo corporal en Tayikistán es un paso legal importante para proteger a los niños.

**Próximo paso** – Los países planean ampliar estos programas. Tayikistán quiere expandir su sistema de reporte escolar a nivel nacional para 2030. Otras regiones seguirán ofreciendo capacitación, apoyo y reformas para ayudar a más sobrevivientes y prevenir la violencia.

**Resumen en una frase** – En siete años, la iniciativa Spotlight ha logrado cambios duraderos que ayudan a mujeres y niñas en todo el mundo a encontrar seguridad, justicia y nuevas oportunidades.
